parties' usually separate seating arrangements. New York's two senators, Democrats Kirsten Gillibrand and Chuck Schumer , also sat alongside Republican senators. They both reacted positively to Barack Obama 's speech. Kirsten Gillibrand said Barack Obama laid out a bold vision for this Congress. She called last year's election, in which Republicans gained control of the House and picked up seats in the Senate ''a mandate for action,'' rather than ''for any one political party.''

refused to say whether he would have acted differently had he known then what he knows now about Saddam Hussein 's alleged weapons. ''I have no idea. I have no idea,'' he said. What you know today can help you on things you're thinking about tomorrow. It can't help you with things you were thinking about back then. Then the fans returned the favor with raucous ovations he won't soon forget. That's when you get the goose bumps, Allen Iverson said. ''You honestly don't really feel it when the shots are going down. You don't ever get the goose bumps until the fans start to appreciate what you're doing out there.''
